text:
The following content is
provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help
MIT OpenCourseWare

continue to offer high-quality
educational resources for free. To make a donation or
view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

PROFESSOR: All right
welcome back, everyone. I can't wait to hear about
your projects and trips.

So today you guys are
going to do presentations. Then we're going to go
through a really quick review

of the design process,
which is appropriate, because we have a really quick
design process to go through.

And then you guys
will do probably no brainstorming--
maybe a little, but then doing Pugh
charts to figure out

what projects make sense for the
class to work on the semester. And then part of
that will be you're going to do micro presentations
at the end of the class

that you'll prep during
class so that you guys can select what projects you're
going to work on tonight.

Are there any questions or
anything to note while you-- before we get started?

OK. And so ideally, we'll do
GrupoFenix, first, and then ASAPROSAR, and then AsoFenix.

OK, so do you guys
want to start?

AUDIENCE: So hi, everyone. For those of you who
don't know, [INAUDIBLE].. We're GrupoFenix. We traveled to
Sabana Grande, which

is 20 minutes south
of Ocotal, which is one of the bigger cities in
Nicaragua, for spring break.

And we were there for five, six
days, and we had a lot of fun. So the first thing
I'll talk about--
this is our group. I'll talk about our group. AUDIENCE: That's Jorge. AUDIENCE: And Jorge--

I guess we should
introduce ourselves. I'm Jessica. AUDIENCE: I'm Vivian. AUDIENCE: Liz--
AUDIENCE: Kurt-- AUDIENCE: Sid-- AUDIENCE: Juan-- AUDIENCE: Beautiful. And this is Jorge. He is the shop manager field--

onsite field manager guy. He's the go-to guy. Basically, you hear
his name over 300 times
in an hour being shouted. Jorge, get us this. Jorge, get us that-- so really handy guy.

Were we able to give
him a D-Lab [INAUDIBLE]?? No-- so next time.

So we're not going to
talk about this first. We're going to talk about
the charcoal burn first. So when we got
there, the itinerary

was to do a lot
of charcoal burns, because that was one
of our projects-- possible projects to work on. And there's a lot of
opportunity there,

because when we got
there on Monday, we had our first burn with
them, and they showed us

the briquettes
that they had been able to make from
their Friday burn.

And this is what came out of it. And as you see it
from-- if you remember from our briquette making--
it's really great, especially

when you compare it to the
blackness of this darker charcoal, which is
a successful burn and a successful briquette
made while we were there.

So this is what
we made with them. This is what they had made the
Friday before we got there. And there was improvement-- yay.

In this picture, you
see all the white smoke, which is basically the water
vapor from the barrel burning.

And it's because, when
they used the Friday-- this was used in
the same biomass that they used Friday,
which is this corn stock.

And this corn stock
apparently wasn't dry enough. It seemed like it
was dry enough, but only when we
were burning it did

we see that it wasn't actually
dry enough for the briquettes. At the end of our
week there, we were

able to make over 150
briquettes from the two burns. And so we yielded
150 briquettes.

Before they were only
making six to seven of these briquettes
for each charcoal burn. And they were looking
at those frantically,

because when we got
there, they already expressed that they did have
a big interest in charcoal making, because
they're starting--

this is a solar center, and
on the other side of the field is the restaurant that they're
going to start operating.

And one of the fuels
that they want to use is charcoal briquettes to
cook in the restaurant.

So they wanted to make this
economically feasible and ready to sell for the people
of Sabana Grande,

possibly to resell it to Ocotal. And so we were able to get
a better yield for them.
Some quick lessons learned-- so a little bit of the history-- Amy came in after Judy.

Judy is a random
service volunteer that came to the
women of Totogalpa, to the Solar Women of
Totogalpa, and taught them

how to do the charcoal burns. But apparently she taught them
completely wrong, because she-- the timing on covering the--

on sealing the barrel,
like we all know, was off. And so because of
that, they were only yielding six to seven, and
it was burning too much,

so it was getting ashy. She didn't teach
them little checks.

So what we did-- I'm sorry-- what we did is
that Kurt and I sat down with two charcoal
captains, we called them.

Two of the women were
made charcoal captains, because Kurt and I
briefed them extensively for like a four-hour
period and instructed them

on what the instructions
meant, the diagrammed ones that we have in Spanish.

And so we went over
the translations, because the Spanish that it
was translated into sometimes was a little different
in Nicaraguan,

so we did that
translation so that they could understand it better. And then we made
them in charge of--

as captains, they
chose to other women, and that-- those four women
were the charcoal committee.

So these two women,
the captains, instructed the other two
women on the process. So now it's a little bit
more of an internal thing.

You also learn better
when you teach, right? And so by the time that
we got there on Thursday, we regrouped.

And on Thursday we did the
charcoal burn in the morning, with all four of them
just leading the way.

They would say every step of
the process before they did it, and it showed that they
really picked up on it.

And by the afternoon, they
did another burn basically completely by themselves. The successful key
points that they really--

that really showed us that they
knew what they were talking about was when we would ask
them in the middle of it all, just to check, how do
you know if it's good--

if it's a good burn? And they would say, oh,
you got to crack it open, and the heart has to be black. And I would say, OK.

How do if the
biomass is too wet? They would say,
oh, because you'd have a lot of white
smoke, and that's bad.

And I'm like, so what's
the yellow smoke then? And then they'd say, oh,
those are the contaminants. And I'm like, contaminants?

But that's what
the wood has when you're cooking with it, right? And they go, no, it's
different, because-- and then they would be able to
explain all the process and all

the logic, and really
get to the why of things. Kurt-- AUDIENCE: Cool.

For the Thursday burns
that Jess described, we went out to the
fields and collected biomass that had been
sitting there for a month.

So it was way drier. And so this prompted us to think
about a possible project for us

to work on-- at least something
to think about, which is whether to bring
the biomass into the center

and burn it there or figure
out some way of being able to do the
burns at the fields

where all this dry biomass is. And because Sabana Grande's
quite a large area,

we thought maybe that
could be something that we could think about,
particularly from the cost perspective, which Liz is going
to talk about in a little bit.

But other things that
we're looking at as far as possible projects are
also this solar dryer

had with the process was having
to air dry these briquettes for three to four days outside.

And they didn't want to
take them outside each day and then have to
bring them back in, and then be worried
always about the rain.

So they work on these-- their primary work is
on the solar ovens,

but they also do solar dryers. So we experimented a little
bit with using these, and we think that one
project we could work on

is a solar dryer specifically
for charcoal briquettes so they can start making
these really quickly as--

almost like a
factory so that they can supply them to
their restaurant

and achieve scale there. And so this shows some
more of the process.

This is the new biomass that we
brought in that was way dryer. This is our second burn.

And this was the
briquette making process.

So one other thing
that we thought could be a potential
project is experimenting

with the like cornstarch
versus yuca versus using banana starch, because they have--
they can just by cornstarch

there pretty cheaply, and
it's much easier for them to do that than have to grind
up this yuca for binder.

So those are basically
the range of projects that we're thinking about
right now, as far as charcoal.

And if you want to talk a little
bit about the cost study now-- AUDIENCE: So we
also, really quickly, did cost study so that we
could ensure that teaching them

charcoal was actually useful,
because they basically wanted to get paid 10 cordoba an hour--
which is like $0.50 an hour--

and work seven-hour days. And so based on those
numbers and roughly

how many burns we thought
they could do in one day, if they just did like
a bunch of burns in one

day and just had a few
going at a time maybe, we thought that they
would be able to sell it for slightly cheaper than you
could buy it in Ocotal, which

was a 20-minute bus ride away,
so that it could actually be a feasible option. And they also really
wanted to use this charcoal

in their restaurant. So hopefully, if they
really get into this and they get a lot better
at it, then they'll

be able to actually
use charcoal, and it'll be economically viable
as well as a clean alternative.

I'm also going to talk
about solar ovens, which I think-- here we go. This is their solar
oven that they

have all over the solar center. It's sort of the
symbol of solar woman

that we were working with,
because it's something that they build. They paint them
this bright color.

They all work a lot of
hours in the solar center, and then when they build
up a certain number of hundreds of hours, they
can buy one for themselves.

So some of the women
have them at home. And they can use
them to make things like cookies, which you see
here, which they can't actually

make in-- on a wood fire. So a lot of the women
really enjoy them. And while they're not really
a very economically viable

option, they're a way of
bringing the women together, which we thought was
really interesting.

There was a Cornell
group they're working on these solar ovens to
try to improve their insulation and other smaller parts
while we were there,

so we worked a lot with them. And they actually built a
new oven with fiberglass insulation while we
were there, so we

got to see how
they were built. We feel as if there's
not too much more that we can add to that
project, as opposed

to the many other
projects that are there, so really the only projects
that we think we should possibly

pursue with regards
to the solar cookers was the solar dryer
for the charcoal.

And then that was
the final charcoal that was supposed to be before. AUDIENCE: So
[INAUDIBLE] so right

now they make these
panels by hand.

The way it works is that
the group GrupoFenix gets all of the extra small
panels from the US,

and they buy boxes of the panels
that don't pass the test here in the US. And for about 500 of the
small panels, it's about $500.

So it's about $1 a cell-- sorry-- a cell--
so about $1 a cell. The problem is that, out of
the 500 cells that they get,

there's about 100 to 200
broken, depending on the box. So it's more than that.

And so this is a really
intensive project-- process of making the
cells-- the panels. I'm just going to go
over it really quick.

Oh. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] the
setup, like set everything up.

AUDIENCE: You want to
just talk on this slide, or was there another slide? AUDIENCE: Yeah,
it's the next one. OK.

Yeah, so first they
connect them all and they call them
chains, solar cell chains.

They solder everything by hand,
and they test every single cell by hand and every chain by hand.

Then they move these changes
independently to this paper.

And then, after they place
each chain independently, they then add liquid silicon
all over the panels by hand.

And they have to make sure
that it's evenly spread, one, and there are no air bubbles. And then they get
the glass, and they

have to put it evenly on top.  And then, by hand they try to
squish out all the air bubbles

that are still in there. Then they add foam
and add batteries. And this is kind of
a annoying process,

because they have to put
each battery at the same-- two batteries at
the same time so it will have even pressure
across the cells.

And they leave it
there for 24 hours so that the last air
bubbles can escape,

and so that it can be
completely flat and even. So there's obviously
a lot of improvement.

It takes about 24 hours to make
one of the large solar cell-- solar panels. And they produce
about 220 watts.

So some of the [INAUDIBLE]
we were thinking about were-- he mentioned, instead of
having to place the batteries

to heavier pressure,
Maybe just an even way that you can just pull down,
and it holds on the pressure.

We were also thinking about
having some type of vacuum pump

or vacuum chamber
that just removes all the air bubbles so you
don't have to do it by hand.

Oh, there's also another thing. They're thinking about using
ethyl vinyl acetate, instead of

the liquid silicon, to cover
and insulate the solar cells.

The problem with the EVA is
that it has to be heated heated, and then it has-- and then
there's also air bubbles,

even if it does heat up. So another possible
project is a way to heat it maybe using the solar
ovens, which they say they did,

or maybe just--
maybe another way. That could be another
possible project.

OK.  So those are the
large solar panels,

which they use for
their homes and they using the power the restaurant,
and they're also using to power the solar center.

Then they're trying to make
the small solar cell phone chargers, which
you saw last time. And they're trying to
basically model to this.

This is worth $10 in Ocotal,
and it's made in China. The great thing about it
is that it actually comes

with a cell phone battery. It fits most Nokia cell phones. And what you see
on the right side is a charger as well as a lamp.

So not only can you
charge your cell phone-- you can use-- also use the
battery to power up a light. So that would be
the ideal project.

So yeah, that would
be an ideal project. Currently, what they're working
on is just the solar cells.

And because they need
a smaller voltage, and they don't really have
much access to capacitors or resistors, they cut--

go back to-- yeah-- they cut every cell by hand
using this-- using a dremel.

So that's another cause, and
another way to cut the cells, instead of having to do it by
hand, would be another project.

What I have here is a little
old battery cell phone charger. So you basically put
your battery here,

and then you move
around, depending on where your battery is, and
you can charge your cell phone.

You can pass it around
if you want to see it. And so we were thinking
of installing that

to the solar panel so you could
charge any type of battery, not just Nokia, ideally.

What else? AUDIENCE: A main issue with that
is also the cost, because we were having a lot of
trouble figuring out

how you would actually-- using their current system,
their prices would be a lot higher than the China-made one--

AUDIENCE: Yeah. AUDIENCE: --which is hard. AUDIENCE: Yeah. Yeah, right now the
costs are really the biggest issue, the fact that
each solar cell is about $1.

Then the silicon-- they use
about 600 grams of the liquid silicon right now, and that's--

I forget the number. It's all in my head, but I think
it's about $100 for 5 gallons.

And just everything adds up. The labor, I think, is
the most intensive part. They really use about 12 actual
hours, 24 hours with the drying

included. The glass is
relatively expensive, and then there's the
aluminum on the side.

There's also the solar-- the tape, that they
have to do it by hand-- which is not really tape.

It's the little aluminum strips. So that could even
be another project. Maybe have a aluminum tape.

That way, you can use tape,
instead of having to solder on. That could be another
great project.

So we're going to
keep talk-- oh, and [? Mario. ?] There are
two people that really make the solar cells right now, which
is the guy in the top left,

which is [? Mario. ?] And then
there's another [? Mario, ?] which is like little [? Mario ?]
and big [? Mario-- ?] who's the only male member of
the cooperative of the Solar
Women of Totogalpa. Yep. That's about it.

AUDIENCE: Cool.  So once we spent a
couple of days there,

we realized that a
lot of the center is focused specifically
towards 20 women who

are part of the cooperative. And so again, wondering, if
we did design a project based

on what we learned
at the center, would it only benefit
those 20 people, or would it help the
surrounding area in general?

And so this is
actually the only slide that we have for that
part, but basically,

what we decided to do
is me and [? Kwan ?] walked a couple of kilometers
down into another district

called Santa Domingo. And this is the
road we walked on. And so Santa Domingo does
not have great electricity,

so they're basically cut
off from any conventional electrical appliances.

And so we wanted to
go there and ask them what their involvement
with the center was, if they had considered
other options for solar,

or wind, or whatever. And so we asked them
a bunch of questions.

So the first thing
we asked them was if they'd heard of charcoal. And we interviewed 10 families,
and none of them used charcoal.

Three of the
families hadn't even heard of carbon,
which is what-- yeah. So they didn't know what it was.

We then went on to ask them
what they did use to cook, and they all said firewood.

We asked them where they
get the firewood from. All of them get the firewood
from their surrounding communities, but
there was actually

one woman who walked
3 kilometers every day just to get firewood,
which we thought
was kind of unfortunate.

We also asked them
after that if they do use some form of lighting
at night, and if so, what?

All the families we
interviewed did have some kind of lamps at night. Mostly they were diesel lamps.

We weren't sure exactly
how they worked, but they all either used diesel
or ocote, which is pinewood,

or electric lamps,
which run on batteries. So once they said that
they do use batteries,

we asked them what they
did use batteries for. And it turned out that they
basically used batteries for three things--

lighting, radios, and if
they're big 9-volt batteries,

then you could power
a cell phone charger. So once we asked
them about that,

we also asked them about how
many cell phones they have, or if they did have
any, per family.

And four out of nine of the
families we interviewed had cell phones, but
the rest didn't.

And for the families that
did have cell phones, we asked them how
they charge them, because they weren't
near the grid.

So apparently, what
they do is they walk to a house
which is in the--

which is in Sabana Grande
to charge their cell phones, and are charged 5 to 10 cordoba
for each cycle of recharging.

Apart from that, we also
asked them if they had cycles. This was just out of curiosity,
because we were wondering

if pedal power was any-- if it was viable. And every family did
have at least one cycle.

Oh, yeah, so a
cell phone battery

charges for 5 to 10 cordoba,
and a 12-volt battery charges for 30 cordoba.

That was pretty much it. We just wanted to
get some perspective on off-grid communities.

And yeah, that's pretty
much-- that's what--

AUDIENCE: OK. PROFESSOR: You guys are supposed
to do a 10-minute presentation, so if you can just go-- AUDIENCE: OK. Real quick.

OK, so while Juan and Sid were
doing off-grid interviews, Liz and I did some interviews
at the different homes

of the women, and
we also had a day where we cooked
with the women, just to gauge their
usage of charcoal,

whether they're using it
or not, and reasons why, and just to really get
an insider's perspective.

So we found out that most people
aren't using the charcoal. They prefer to cook
with wood over charcoal,

basically because they
can gather it for free. They have to pay to
buy the charcoal. They don't have to go
to Ocotal to buy it.

And they say tortillas are a
very big part of their diet.

They get up early every
morning, go to the [INAUDIBLE] to grind the corn, go
through this process, and they make tortillas
every single day.

So it's a very huge
part of their diet. And they found that the
charcoal doesn't burn hot enough

to make the tortillas, so
they prefer using wood. And also, on their
adobe stoves, you

can cook multiple
things at once, which is also why they prefer wood.

So this was a good
inside look at why they're not using charcoal.

And we also saw, when we were
cooking with one of the women, that she kept on using
tinders from the wood fire--

from that wood fire and she's
dumping it into the charcoal to try to light it. She was having a really
hard time doing that.

And a very small side project is
just better charcoal education.

And I think it's going to
be really important to make this charcoal affordable
so that they will see this

as an option over wood. Another thing we surveyed
the families about

was their electricity usage. And we noticed that most people,
if they had solar panels,

they were bought
using green hours. And because these
families don't--

they don't want to pay the
extra amount for an inverter, so other solar panels are used
for lighting in their homes.

Some families are lucky enough
to pay for-- to have enough money to pay for
grid electricity, which they use to
charge cell phones and--

some families have
TVs and radios.

Other families that are only
dependent on solar panel energy, who also
have cell phones,

we saw go to their
friends' houses to charge phones, which
gave us the idea of having

maybe a community charger,
community solar power-- yeah, some of
center where we can

invest in various
panels that does have an inverter to maybe
charge these cell phones,

instead of them borrowing
their friends' grid electricity and stuff like that. Yeah.

I don't know if
there's anything else. Oh, and these are some of
the homes we stayed in. And we had a good time
staying with them,

and learned a lot just from
living their everyday routines and stuff like that.

I think that's about it. If anyone else has
anything to add-- AUDIENCE: Any questions?

Ideas, comments? AUDIENCE: We have
a lot of projects.

PROFESSOR: Yeah. So today you guys are
going to have to-- AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: --work hard
to narrow them down. [INAUDIBLE]

AUDIENCE: Sorry for
going over time. PROFESSOR: Thank you. AUDIENCE: Thanks. [APPLAUSE]

AUDIENCE: So hi, everyone. We were working with ASAPROSAR
in Santa Ana, El Salvador.

And while we were there, we
worked on two main projects just to show them and work
with them to demonstrate.

We did three charcoal
burns, and we showed three
different communities how to make corn
shellers for themselves--

so bringing down a project
that had already been done. We're just going to run
through some of our pictures from charcoal and
explain how that one.

So at first, they didn't
have an oil barrel when we went down
there, so we had to go to the cooperative
in one of the communities

and find an oil barrel, first
of all, and then find someone to cut the holes for us. So Miguel was kind enough
to drill our holes.

And then we brought it to
the community, and we just-- we did three
different communities

on three different days. And all three communities
that we went to were really eager to help.

They all wanted to
be a part of it. This particular
guy right here was part of a community that was
looking at charcoal more of--

as an economic goal, I guess. They wanted to sell the
charcoal, as opposed

to using it, because they had
just acquired new stoves where they were using wood that
were outside, so they're

better for ventilation. So these are just some of
the pictures from that.

They were all really
excited about the charcoal. But the first day, our
burn didn't go so well.

We learned that using pretty
wet sugar cane wasn't great.

They hadn't dried up very well,
and sugar cane to start with was a lot more dense than
some of the material we had used when we burned here.

And we just didn't let
it burn long enough. But it was also good
for the community to see that, if they didn't
let it burn long enough, then

they wouldn't get
good charcoal from it. Did you want to add anything? AUDIENCE: And another
thing we realized

is that, when-- the first day,
when we grated the yuca, we did it in relatively bigger pieces,
so it was still pretty dry,

didn't release any
of, I guess, the juice or whatever it has in it. So when we ground it up,
it was still really dry,

and so when we added it to
the water to make the binder, we had to use so
much yuca to get it
to have that right consistency.

The one yuca didn't make
a whole lot of binder, so we learned to put it
in smaller pieces to make.

AUDIENCE: You can
see how thick it was. This was the first day. AUDIENCE: It's really thick. AUDIENCE: I think
it's important to note

that, in all communities,
people were-- some people were somewhat
familiar with charcoal.

Sometimes they had no idea. But it was really
nice that everybody--

I guess we kind
of expected that, but everybody worked
with us, and they came up with their own little ideas.

I guess the two tour guides-- not tour guides--
that's a bad word-- the two people helping
us from the organization,

asked them to do
the demonstration, and we were checking in and
making sure everything's OK. So that worked out
really well in terms

of involving the community
actually to keep doing this,

because they're going
to keep showing people in different communities,
so it was important for us

to involve them a
lot in the process. AUDIENCE: They
got it down really fast, so by the third day,
when we let them run it, we--

it was all in Spanish and we
couldn't follow most of it, so we would ask our translator,
Juan Carlos, who was working

with us, and one
of the two people who was working
in the community--

we asked him, oh, did you
remember to tell them this? He was like, yeah, yeah,
yeah, yeah, I got it. I got it. AUDIENCE: He was
such a help to us.

AUDIENCE: He was a total pro. So it was really good. It's really exciting
to know that they'll have the know-how
and the confidence

to really accurately
tell more communities how to make the charcoal.

AUDIENCE: This Is Elena. She was one of the
other community partners that we worked with. She was really into the
motivational aspect of it,

so she'd always be
like, [SPANISH].. You can do it. She kept encouraging the
people in the community that--

who are a little
more nervous about it or who are more depressed
about their living conditions, that they
could keep moving forward.

So she was really excited
about the charcoal.
[INAUDIBLE]

AUDIENCE: It was a lot of
fun that pretty much everyone in the community was
really involved with it.

At least on the last
day, we really sat back and didn't really
do anything, and let Juan Carlos and Elena
take the reins--

at least with the instruction. But still the entire time
the members of the community were really doing everything,
and they jumped right in.

No one was really very hesitant. And there was something a
little bit for everyone to do.

When we crushed up
the charcoal, there were a lot of kids in
the area, so they just went to town stomping
on the rice bags.

It was really a lot of fun.  The person that was-- drove
us to the [INAUDIBLE] what was

that-- AUDIENCE: Julio-- AUDIENCE: Julio-- one day
he sat there and just made

charcoal briquette after
charcoal briquette. He was like, oh, look
at the ones I've made. Everyone was really excited
about it, so that was nice.

AUDIENCE: So with
the corn shellers, [INAUDIBLE] had gone down, and
some of the communities had

seen-- or had heard about
using cans that they had to make the corn shellers. So we had never
heard of that, but we

were trying to go with it. And the first day
that we went out, we had to experiment with
using pliers and the cans

that they had. So this was one
of the communities that-- they were just
playing around with it.

And it was almost good in
a way that we didn't really know how to do it
ourselves perfectly, because it allowed them to
experiment themselves with it.

They found the best ways
that they wanted to make it. They're using little
6-ounce jalapeno cans.

So these are someone the
woman playing around with it. And then we also
did show them how to use the jig with the
sheet metal and the hammer.

One of the things that
we ran into, though, was one of the communities
didn't have pliers,

so we had to show them how to do
the whole thing with a hammer. And eventually,
by the third day,

we came up with this idea of
having a variable corn sheller. So we didn't actually close
it, and we rounded the edges

so it was just like--
could hold it in your hand and adjust it to the
size of the corn, because the corn varied a lot
from different communities.

So that was really helpful, and
this girl was really into it. AUDIENCE: It was nice
when we found the way

to do it without fully
attaching the ends so that, since a lot of the
corn were different sizes,

you would see a lot of the
members of the community use one corn shell
and try to shell it, and it didn't work because
it wasn't the right size.

So they'd toss it out
and try another one. And you could see it
was kind of frustrating. Who wants a corn sheller
that doesn't actually work?

So once we figured
out how to do it with just rounding
the edges so you could just the-- how tightly
you gripped it made it

work for every single corncob. It was a lot more exciting. And when we first showed
it to them that day,

the lady tried it, and
promptly put it in her pocket, and went around with
the rest of the day.

It was amazing. AUDIENCE: The third community
we went to actually-- we went and toured
houses and looked

at stoves in between,
when we had first showing them how to make them. And we came back

and they were still all

Now we're going to talk to you
about some potential projects we came up with.

So the second problem that

Some of the communities

They [? spent ?]
well over their-- a couple days' salary

that they used to use to

To make it softer,
they had-- some of the communities had put

of the mill. But they found
that the rubber was turning the rice kernels

So we bought a couple
mills and experimented with other materials, which
included a lighter color rubber

material and leather. So it was more organic material
to place in between it.

Saturday before we left, and we had a decent

In terms of day lighting-- so
the houses were completely--

AUDIENCE: Very dark-- AUDIENCE: Very dark-- some of

Sometimes they didn't

a couple of different issues. One was money.

Because the houses were
made with adobe bricks, in order to leave--

it seems simple that you just
leave an opening so that you actually save on material. However, for safety,
and also for hurricanes,

they have to close that opening. And to close that opening,
if they use wood or metal,

it costs anywhere
around $25 per window, whereas the bricks are $0.30. So that's $30 versus $25--

is a big difference. Another issue they
said was some of them

didn't actually want more light
because of privacy reasons. Parents and kids sometimes
are in the same room,

so they were kind of joking
around, but they said, we can't do anything because,
if you can see things--

kids are always aware of
what the parents are doing, and the other way around. So it was more of
a privacy issue.

However, day lighting
could be improved, or it would be great if
they have more light for all

of the tasks they're working. And some of the ideas
we had were, again,
using existing materials. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

that got to go and see

was a biodigester. Yes, this is the same
one that we went and saw

in a town called [INAUDIBLE]. It's hooked up to

Yes. Yeah, power has
come to [INAUDIBLE],, but people still
cook on wood stoves.

And a great way
to supplement that is with methane from
biodigesters like this one. So this one belonged
to a household

where the woman cooked
twice a day on it. But it would often run out. She'd have really no idea how
much gas it was producing.

So one of the projects
we went down there with was to make some of simple,
yet elegant meter for her

to tell just how much gas was in
a pressure meter, essentially.

Do we have a picture? Yes. OK, so our simple [? compo ?]
engineering solution was

to take a piece of clear
tubing we had brought, mark off some in increments so
you could see whether or not

the gas coming in
from the tank-- which is the gray piece
of conduit there--

would press against the water. So basically, you would read
where the water in the tube

meant the air, and it would
indicate if the pressure had risen or fallen. Yeah.

So it's also a pressure
release system, which is really important
if the bag gets too--

you don't want
the bag to get too over-filled with gas and the
pressure to get too high. So basically, if the pressure
somehow got to the end of that

6 and 1/2 inches of tube--
which is highly unlikely, since she uses it every day-- the gas would simply just
bubble up to the top.

However, there were
some difficulties that we noticed, like with the
daily feeding this machine--

or this system, just
basic use of it. We hopefully solved that
one with this simple meter.

But another one was just
it's a very messy task. Basically, it's a whole 5-gallon
bucket of manure that has to be

mixed in a one-part manure,
three-part water mixture, and then added, and
then poured through--

if we go back to the picture
of the entire system-- AUDIENCE: I think I might have-- AUDIENCE: --poured through
a relatively narrow pipe.

And it's just very
sloppy and messy. It's-- also entails mixing
the manure and the water

in a bucket. She had a little trowel
that she did it with. [INAUDIBLE] and I got nice and
dirty giving it a try as well.

And yeah, it's just
a messy procedure. If we could come up
with some of device that would mix the
slurry in the bucket,

as well as aid in pouring
it, not only would it make this a lot
easier to use and be

able to make her-- or help
her get her chores done much faster, but it would
make biodigesters

less messy in general. And I think that's-- imagine that would be
an applicable market for biodigesters in the
states, biodigesters

in other developing countries. It would be a very
transmutable project.

AUDIENCE: So our last project
was a millet thresher, which--

this is millet here on the
head, and this is the raw grain

after the processing. So in the town of
[? El Jocote, ?] they--

most of the families
grow millet. And the processing of this
plant takes a long time.

It takes a total-- so to harvest the fields, it
takes between four to six days

of one man working. So they normally
have two men do it. It takes between two and
three days to do that.

Then they wait 8 to 15
days for the heads to dry-- or for the stalks to dry.

And then they cut the heads
off of the stalks, which takes

another two to four man days. And then the long,
time-consuming part

is knocking the
little pieces of grain off of the head of the stock.

And the way they do this
is they have this device-- or platform here, where
they stand on that plank,

and then take the stick
and hit the heads. And then the grain falls out,
because that's just pieces--

individual sticks going across
the bottom of the platform, so the grains just fall
through onto the tarp.

Normally they'd have a bigger
tarp at the bottom of this, but they just saved the
one bag, and their harvest

had ended before we got there. But Jaime, the
director of AsoFenix,

requested that they
save a bag to show us, so this is just one bag. They would normally
have a bigger tarp.

And then there's a guy
below who's sweeping, and that's because parts of
the head stock-- not the grain,

but the head stock--
also fall down. And he's sweeping
those black bits out of the pile of pure grain.

So normally in their
process, they'd have two men on the
plank-- one man sweeping, and then another man loading
more raw material up on top.

So it's a four-man
process, and it takes anywhere between 4
and 10 days for each family

to process their
harvest, depending on their size of
the field, depending on the yield for that year.

So it's a lot of time, because
that's four men working for 4 to 10 days. So that's upwards of 40 man
days to complete this task.

The men don't like doing this
work, so there's a very easy-- if the machine works,
they will use it.
